comments:
I was working with Eclipse, when suddenly a dialog box was popping up, informing
me that an out of memory exception has occured and it would be safest to exit
eclipse right now. So I left Eclipse immediately by pressing the appropriate button.

When I no try to restart Eclipse, I get a dialog box saying
"An error has occured. See the log file c:\eclipse\workspace\.metadata\.log."

I tried several times, but no success. What do I have to do to be able to reopen
my workspace again?

Are there no more exceptions added to the log when the workspace fails to start?
 It looks like the last entries in the log are the OutOfMemoryErrors, so it is
difficult to see what is preventing it from starting up.  Most of the exceptions
are due to a corrupt history store (a component we have since completely
replaced in the 3.1 stream).  These exceptions are caught and logged, but should
not be preventing the next session from starting.

I just tried once more to start Eclipse. The following lines have been added to
the .log file:

!SESSION Jan 10, 2005 16:10:50.362 ---------------------------------------------
eclipse.buildId=M200409161125
java.version=1.4.2_05
java.vendor=Sun Microsystems Inc.
BootLoader constants: OS=win32, ARCH=x86, WS=win32, NL=de_CH

!ENTRY org.eclipse.osgi Jan 10, 2005 16:10:50.362
!MESSAGE Application error
!STACK 1
java.lang.OutOfMemoryError


Sorry, nothing more. What can I do now to continue working?

Can you try deleting or renaming the following file:

c:\eclipse\workspace\.metadata\.plugins\org.eclipse.core.resources\.history\.index

This will tell us if the history store corruption is the cause of the startup
failure, and if so, it will allow you to reopen the workspace

You can also try increasing the size of the Java heap, for example:

eclipse -vmargs -Xmx300M

Again, this is not the solution for the error, but it might allow the VM to
proceed far enough to write out a more useful error message.

Your first tip (about renaming the .index file) did not change anything.
The second tip (using -vmargs -Xmx300M) in fact produces a more useful error 
message, but I'am still not able to start Eclipse. I append the new .log file 
to the message.

When I look at the exception stack and see "org.eclipse.swt.SWTError: No more 
handles", I'am asking myself whether it could have had an influence that many 
browser windows were opened - just before the out of memory exception occured 
when I was working, I thought that may be I should close some windows as the 
system was really slow (however, I do not remember exactly how much windows 
have been open).

Another ideas how I can start working with Eclipse again?

Moving to UI based on this latest information.  The history store corruption
clearly isn't the cause of the startup failure, since deleting the history index
will regenerate the history store from scratch.

The operating system has a limit on the number of image handles that can be
held.  You are hitting this limit, and since the failure occurs on startup it is
preventing you from continuing.  This is usually caused by someone "leaking"
image handles (creating but not disposing them).

It is possible that you have some extra plugin that is causing the failure (I
noticed the Subversion plugin, for example).  Here is another thing you can try
to get going.  Try renaming the file:

eclipse\workspace\.metadata\.plugins\org.eclipse.ui.workbench\workbench.xml.

This file contains a description of the saved UI layed (the opened views and
editors).  It looks like one of the views that you had open at the time of the
last shutdown is causing the problem.  Deleting the description will cause
Eclipse to restart in the default perspective with no custom views.

If this fixes your problem, please attach the workbench.xml file to this bug so
we can diagnose further (see the "Create a New Attachment" link above).

Removing the workbench.xml actually solved the problem - Eclipse is starting up 
and I'am able to work again.

As you requested, I will attach the workbench.xml file as an attachment.

Thanks for your prompt help.

I'm not sure where to log this.  Mvm, you might want to move to [WorkbenchParts]
and assign to SX.  Alternatively, you could movie it to [Workbench] and keep it
assigned to you...

this looks like a duplicate of bug 82298, if this is a repeatable case, I wonder
if you could try on a build from today

I don't think it's a duplicate.  The originator is running on the 3.0.1 release,
and bug 82298 was only introduced in December.
Stefan can you have a look at the exception in  comment #6?

The exception in comment 6 indicates that he ran out of handles while creating a
view.

Sadly, it doesn't say much about what was actually using the rest of the
handles. I checked out his workbench.xml and nothing jumped out at me besides
the fact that he was using the CDT and had a lot of C editors open at the time.

It seems likely that this is due to a resource leak in one of the CDT or debug
views that were open at the time... but without access to the entire workspace,
we're unlikely to figure out which one.

Closing as worksforme. Please reopen if you discover steps to reproduce.
